guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body:
We should be united in Christ. I believe we can unite if we humble ourself and walk in the Spirit. Anyone with actual faith in Christ may believe the same, cause otherwise you arguably have no actual faith? People who don't take it to heart but intellectualize it or interpret it philosophically or see it as mere structure or fundament for culture while still relying in their senses instead of Christ their Lord will not realize this I assume.

>For we are God’s fellow workers; you are God’s field, you  are  God’s building. According to the grace of God which was given to me, as a wise master builder I have laid the foundation, and another builds on it. But let each one take heed how he builds on it. For no other foundation can anyone lay than that which is laid, which is Jesus Christ.
I Corinthians 3:9‭-‬11 NKJV

body:
God wants us to watch out for false prophets and liars, but I have found that doctrine is not as important as action. The Holy Spirit will work through Christians as He wants to. If we read the Bible, we will know what comes from God and what is human.

We should not concern ourselves in trivial matters of others. I'm not a fan of the schisms between the Christians, and I believe that it only exists amongst the leadership. The Christians on the ground, and even some of the leadership don't give a hoot what your beliefs on congregational procedure are.
body_html:

Bible serves us and the Spirit brings us to the Bible which is also written trough the Spirit. It's a tool with multiple purposes for both believers as well as missionary work in a way in which faith and genuine love is preserved. Spirit is still alive with or without a Bible.

God's Spirit indwells in those that have put their faith (for everything) in Christ as Lord and Savior, and believe in His ressurection. God wants you to accept His abundantly graceful gift of salvation brought forth by the condemnation of His son

parent.body:
God wants us to watch out for false prophets and liars, but I have found that doctrine is not as important as action. The Holy Spirit will work through Christians as He wants to. If we read the Bible, we will know what comes from God and what is human.

We should not concern ourselves in trivial matters of others. I'm not a fan of the schisms between the Christians, and I believe that it only exists amongst the leadership. The Christians on the ground, and even some of the leadership don't give a hoot what your beliefs on congregational procedure are.

body: The original would be the best as I have yet to find a translation that isn't biased and doesn't either make use of ultra complicated religious language or paraphrase it (the words used in the original text were casual and everyday terms, even "Christ" (ΧΡΙΣΤΟΣ) was not a cryptic transliteration but greek for savior, and it was translated from the hebrew word משיח). Unfortunately the pure original no longer exists as we don't have the autographs. I suggest you start with the gospels which contain just about everything you need to know, and then read the other stuff if you want and the questionable parts will probably feel off.

body:
>Great question!

It was a rhetorical question. It don't believe God's spirit indwell and guides willful idolaters and polytheists, i.e. Christians. And the individuals most likely to blasphemously claim they are "saved", indwelled and guided by God's spirit -- Evangelicals, Charismatics, self-professed "born agains" -- are also the most clueless ones, peddling the most modern and baseless bastardization of Christianity, and they always disproves their own blasphemous claims by their own words.

>God is the Word.

The word what exactly? The Nicene-Christian logos?

>He says this in Genesis.

Not really.

>I know God's main way of speaking is the Bible. I don't totally know why. But I can guess.

The Bible as compiled and canonized by the Roman Cathodox mother church of Christianity doesn't claim itself to be God's word, and the concept of sola scriptura wasn't even invented until the 16th century. The modern Evangelical bastardization of the concept much later.

body:
Yes, the parts that are true. Not the forgeries James, 1 & 2 Timothy, Titus, and Jude, probably 1 & 2 Peter, Hebrews, Colossians, Ephesians, and 2 Thessalonians (and possibly Revelation and the Johannine epistles). Or the obvious additions to Paul's letters especially in 1 Corinthians. I never said I didn't believe, but the bible != the word and that is just everyone's misguided assumption (the real word is very clearly identified at the beginning of John, and it's not the bible--so if you think it's the bible, you ironically don't believe the bible). People jump through many confusing hoops to try and get them not to contradict everything else even though all the places that do that are the ones that have a lot of evidence of not being written by who they say they were. That they were forgeries is pretty obvious and makes way more sense than a confusing mess of twisting opposing passages to agree with each other. There's also the possibility that even a true author is simply wrong about something. I mean come on, even the closest disciples were called fools more than anyone else and were absolutely clueless most of the time, can you really trust them 100%? These writings are good for reading but people barely even read the gospels, and they're the ones that literally document everything we need to know. Putting humans on the same level of authority especially when there are malicious forgeries among them creates tons of confusion and contradictions, perverting the very simple message found in all 4 gospels, and that is what we are told to follow, not "the bible" that wasn't even put together until 400 years later. Everything in the bible makes so much more sense when you realize this. You will not find "the bible" in the bible, not even in the forged books, and every canon list and books contained in manuscripts before 382 differs wildly from each other.

I used to think the same way as you and believe everything included in the canon was 100% accurate, but after I started reading even just a little bit of it I realized I'd been tricked and had been getting spoonfed the snippets that were convenient for certain agendas. I later found that all the historical evidence aligns with my suspicions. We removed the apocrypha, I don't see how this is any different. It's not like they stop people from receiving or anything but it does make everything way more complicated and can be misleading.

body: That doesn't mean the bible is perfect. The majority of it isn't even God at all, but merely writings by famous believers. And even the ones that are, the written record isn't what's faultless, but rather what they were recording. Lastly, a few of the books, like genesis, are compilations of oral or written records, basically historical documentation, and don't have much moral value. Differing versions of stories were included and were all appended into a master text. This is why contradictions like the creation story in genesis 1 and 2 exist and have different authors.

body:
> The Word was written by the Holy Spirit acting within the authors, just as the Holy Spirit acted within those who perpetuated the text.

Yes but those people are not perfect. By that logic there would never be any arguments among believers. Zero. Because they would all agree 100% and never get anything wrong.

> God doesn't tell us that he is real and therefore the Bible is perfect. No. God says, if you think the Bible is perfect, then you must know that I am real.

This requires you to start with the bible which doesn't work unless you were raised in that tradition. But in the bible people knew he was real because it was self evident that it is the truth, whether they acknowledged it or not. Plenty of outsiders approached likely not knowing a word of scripture, and yet many of them had even greater faith. On top of that the bible has only existed since 382 AD, and it was not until very recently that the masses had access to it.

> What are the contradictions you are talking about in Genesis?

Genesis 1 tells the story of the 7 day creation that we are all familiar with. Genesis 2 is another version of the story, but in this one Adam is created first after the land and waters, and everything and everyone else is created for him and after him. In many ways this is the opposite of the previous one. Some people try to explain this away by saying it's "pluperfect" so it could mean what *had been* made, but lets be honest that makes no sense with its sentence structure. It's clearly two separate stories too, as the beginning of the second one has the header "An account of the creation of the heavens and the earth" even though that just happened in Genesis 1, and the writing styles are wildly different, you can tell even in a translation. I think the logical conclusion is that there were 2 differing versions of the creation account, and both were put in the collection of these stories now known as Genesis. This is also evident because otherwise scribes would've tried to harmonize it, and the whole book does not have any consistent theme really, it's a bunch of brief texts about the origin of Israel and Judah put together and this is obvious when reading it as a whole.

body:
Frankly, I don't particularly like the fact that people divide the New and Old Testaments. God did not change when he gave Jesus to the world.

And Jesus did not come to form a new religion. Jesus came to clarify some things that caused division amongst the people.

Amongst other things, he told the Pharisees to stop harassing the people on behalf of God. For God hopes to redeem everyone.

Now what I'm curious to is what you refer to when you say pagan things in the church. There can be no worship of pagan gods because God created everything and has given it to His Son, and therefore, it makes no sense to worship a diety that even claims to have less authority than God and his son Jesus. Please clarify about your discussion about paganism, if you are actually trying to educate me.

If you refer to Santa (Satan) Claus, then perhaps we're in agreement. I think Santa is an ugly manifestation of Earthly greed. The Easter Bunny is a false idol to spring cleaning and papering over the fact that we have wallowed in our sins in the winter months. Even the Earthly representations of Jesus are frustrating IMO because God asked us not to make representations of him. God says to show our beliefs in the same way he shows us: with his Word. He tells the Israelites to put His commandments on their doorframes.

And frankly, the worship of the saints is pretty weird too. The dead people who join the Father in heaven don't become angels or even guardian angels. And they themselves were created and molded by God, so it would be more effective to pray to God because anything good in each saint is moreso in God and actually only came from God, not that saint in particular. Frankly, even Jesus only comes from God as the son of a king comes from that king. However, I also praise Jesus for taking the pains of my sins and saving me and my children from the ultimate punishments for my sins.

The globalists want to rebuild on a weak foundation of sand: critical theory, racial conflict, crony capitalism, political corruption, godless nihilist consumerism, etc. We need to build back on the foundation of Christ, family values, life, and fellowship. That’s how we will build back much better than ever before as we watch their foundation of sand collapse on itself.

body:
No shit his letters weren't written by Jewish scholars. The Jewish scholars were too busy worshipping themselves to speak with God. There is a reason Jesus spends so much time rebuking the Pharisees. It's because the Pharisees were leading the people astray. The Pharisees asked who had the authority to clear God's temple of deceiptful merchants and userers. The Pharisees had punished a homeless man for moving his bedroll on the Sabbath, yet they allowed merchants to claim God's temple as a market. How can you tell me that the Pharisees knew God? Did God tell the Israelites to treat the foreign merchant different from the foreign homeless man? Or did God tell the Israelites to treat all foreigners with kindness and respect out of rememberance of their enslavement to the Egyptians?

And also, imagine if there was a time in the Old Testament where God did not answer the prayers of the Israelites merely because it was the Sabbath. Did God tell the Israelites to remove guards from their walls on the day of the Sabbath? And which day did the Israelites at the walls of Jericho take their Sabbath? Did they do any work on that day or did they find it merely merry enjoyment to march their rams horns around the walls of Jericho seven times?

Oh, also, the story of the Samaritan was priceless. God tells us in Leviticus to cleanse yourself if you had touched the blood of another person and to not infect others while you are unclean. So the Pharisees would not step up to help an injured man because he was covered in blood, and they had no time to cleanse themselves and therefore could not help. Imagine if God was so petty as to not put his hands on us when we are covered in our own blood or dirty from the trials of this Earth. David even proclaims that God protects us when we are broken and bloodied by our enemies. He does not forsake us merely because we have gotten ourselves dirty.

What do you think Paul got wrong in his letters?

The Pauline epistles was written by a man that didn't know anything about the Hebrew Bible period.

body:
Lo-ammi is just one of many signs that God is treated unfaithfully by the Israelites. It's far from the only time the Israelites forsaked God. Read through Kings remember how God tore down the temple. Remember the tribe of Juda who took in the king who forsaked God from the beginning. God told them that he would specifically preserve Judah despite the fact that they would forsake him constantly.

Did Judah rule over the Israelites during the Old Testament after that? Or did the Old Testament talk mostly about the kings who ruled outside of Juda? And what about Ruth? Was Ruth in conflict with Ezra when Ezra told the Israelites to get rid of their strange wives?

And if God had made Jerusalem the city of his love as part of Judah, why didn't the whole Old Testament take place there? Why was the old testament spread out amongst all of Israel? If someone is an Israelite but not from the tribe of Judah, how can you say you have God's blessing if you claim that the Moabites don't receive God's blessing if they worship God?

And if you are from the tribe of Judah, don't you think it's interesting that God said that your tribe/nation would specifically be amongst the biggest rebels against God?

"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

parent.body:
>No shit his letters weren't written by Jewish scholars.

They weren't written by any Jew period. And you're literally the one calling it God's word. Also, according to Acts Paul was a prominent student of Gamaliel. 

>What do you think Paul got wrong in his letters?

Every single thing. It's a trainwreck. He didn't know seed in Hebrew, zera, is the same in singular and plural (Gal. 3:16), not did he understand simple context. What kind of a Jew and student of Gamaliel don't know basic Hebrew? He taught Lo-Ammi was a prophecy about gentiles. He called the ones following the sign of God's covenant dogs and mutilaters of the flesh. What kind of Jew talks like that about the sign of God's covenant? He called the law a curse, and completely flipped and perverted ever simple clear-cut Torah scripture. He falsely juxtaposed faith and law. His writings only doesn't contain a single word suggesting he was even remotely familiar with Pharisaical doctrine. The Pauline epistles was written by a man that didn't know anything about the Hebrew Bible period.

body:
> Oh, so the Torah Israel was required to keep as affirmed by every prophet was corrupted(but not the prophetic writings themselves conveniently)? Good luck with that theory.

Yes, and any references they have to it is from later redactions, and no the prophetic writings are also corrupt, they're completely out of order half the time. Before the time of Josiah none of the people in the bible were aware of hardly any of the laws and that is evident by their actions. For example David was a Moabite and so were his priests...something that according to the Torah is offense deserving of being *stoned to death*. The Torah also has commandments to make animal sacrifices to please God with the "savory aroma". What pagan nonsense! And then we see God *complaining* about sacrifices being made in multiple of the prophets. Read the whole of Jeremiah chapters 7-8, there are attacks on several of the laws followed by the comment about the corrupt scribes. It's difficult to reinterpret this as being about external works. Interpolation was a common practice in the ancient world, and God specifically says they don't have his law, and the reason they don't have his law is because the scribes had not been honest with it. Combined with several commands to *not* do things which are commanded in the Torah, it's hard to bend this any other way.

> And Imagine thinking Paul was the one that got it right in his trainwreck that doesn't even line up with Jesus and the gospels.

When you get rid of the fake letters and interpolations from the church fathers it lines up very closely. But I believe you're mistaken, I don't listen to Paul before Jesus.
body_html:
Oh, so the Torah Israel was required to keep as affirmed by every prophet was corrupted(but not the prophetic writings themselves conveniently)? Good luck with that theory.

Yes, and any references they have to it is from later redactions, and no the prophetic writings are also corrupt, they're completely out of order half the time. Before the time of Josiah none of the people in the bible were aware of hardly any of the laws and that is evident by their actions. For example David was a Moabite and so were his priests...something that according to the Torah is offense deserving of being stoned to death. The Torah also has commandments to make animal sacrifices to please God with the "savory aroma". What pagan nonsense! And then we see God complaining about sacrifices being made in multiple of the prophets. Read the whole of Jeremiah chapters 7-8, there are attacks on several of the laws followed by the comment about the corrupt scribes. It's difficult to reinterpret this as being about external works. Interpolation was a common practice in the ancient world, and God specifically says they don't have his law, and the reason they don't have his law is because the scribes had not been honest with it. Combined with several commands to not do things which are commanded in the Torah, it's hard to bend this any other way.

And Imagine thinking Paul was the one that got it right in his trainwreck that doesn't even line up with Jesus and the gospels.

When you get rid of the fake letters and interpolations from the church fathers it lines up very closely. But I believe you're mistaken, I don't listen to Paul before Jesus.
